SMA_embolism.location: Usually 3-10 cm from ostium (beyond middle colic)
SMA_embolism.history: Atrial fibrillation, recent MI, heart failure

SMA_thrombosis.history: Chronic mesenteric ischemia symptoms (food fear, weight loss)

mesenteric_venous_thrombosis.risk_factors: Hypercoagulable states, portal hypertension, malignancy, intra-abdominal sepsis
mesenteric_venous_thrombosis.imaging: CT shows SMV thrombus, bowel wall thickening

NOMI.setting: ICU, post-cardiac surgery, vasopressors, digoxin toxicity

presentation.classic: Sudden severe periumbilical pain 'out of proportion to exam'
presentation.late: Peritonitis, bloody stool, hemodynamic instability (bowel necrosis)

laboratory.lactate: Elevated late - indicates necrosis, not early ischemia

imaging.findings: Arterial occlusion, venous thrombosis, bowel wall enhancement/non-enhancement, pneumatosis

SMA_thrombosis.surgical: Bypass (aorta-SMA or iliac-SMA) if peritonitis or endovascular fails

MVT.anticoagulation: Primary treatment; surgery only for peritonitis

NOMI.correct_underlying: Stop vasoconstrictors if possible, optimize cardiac output

second_look.indication: Bowel viability uncertain at initial operation

prognosis.factors: Delay in diagnosis, extent of necrosis, comorbidities

definition.@value: Management algorithm for acute mesenteric ischemia addressing the four etiologies (embolism, thrombosis, venous, NOMI) with rapid CTA diagnosis and early revascularization strategies.

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Differentiate the four etiologies of acute mesenteric ischemia
Understand the role of second-look laparotomy
clinical_pearls: Pain out of proportion to exam + atrial fibrillation = think SMA embolism
SMA thrombosis often has PRIOR symptoms of chronic mesenteric ischemia
Lactate is a LATE finding - indicates necrosis, not early ischemia
CTA is gold standard - 94% sensitive, 95% specific
Second-look laparotomy at 24-48 hours is ESSENTIAL if viability uncertain
NOMI = vasospasm without occlusion - common post-cardiac surgery, treat underlying cause
